abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Fourth Technical
            Cooperation Project for China were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the project involved a flexible approach in
            subproject proposal review. Quality at entry is essential
            for maintaining high implementation quality. To ensure
            quality at entry, it is important to have a strong and
            competent task manager and task team; well thought out
            interventions; clearly defined project activities; and close
            relations between the requested inputs and the expected
            outcomes. It is also important to provide timely trainings
            to Subproject Implementing Agencies (SIA) staffs and the new
            SIAs in particular, especially in areas of procurement and
            disbursement. Formulate multiple procurement methods, in
            view of the importance of procurement and disbursement in
            ensuring timely implementation completion. Needs assessment
            of project funds should be carried out seriously and
            carefully to avoid cancellation of large volumes of project
            funds. Stabilizing the Task Teams of both the Bank and the
            Borrower; keeping a good filing system and the e-filing
            system in particular, to maintain continuity of the project
            implementation, and to avoid adverse effect caused by the
            task team changes. Cooperation and communications among
            subprojects with similar nature is encouraged, so as to
            achieve information sharing, avoid duplication and promote
            each other's work.

5081600.majtheme: Rural development,Social protection and risk management,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fourth Technical Cooperation Project
            aims to provide continued support to China in its economic
            and structural reform effort. The project consists of two
            components. The first component supports reform and
            institutional development. It supports strengthening the
            institutions involved in the Government's economic
            policies based on Government priorities, provides support to
            programs associated with policy reform; and strengthens the
            capacity of provincial finance bureaus and project
            implementing agencies to manage implementation of Bank and
            non-Bank financed projects involved in fostering sustainable
            development. The second component supports pre-investment
            and project preparation. It finances consultants'
            services, training, and equipment required for the
            preparation of feasibility studies. Subprojects under the
            first component include institutional strengthening of
            Chinese academic institutes and government agencies,
            demonstration zones, and finance bureaus. The second
            component includes subprojects concerned with sustainable
            forestry, water conservation, flood control, water supply,
            agricultural development, and river basin pollution.
